feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 2:30PM AKST until December 4 at 12:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blowing snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 10 inches. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph. Visibility reduced to one half mile.
* WHERE...Thompson Pass.
* WHEN...From 12 PM Tuesday to 12 AM AKST Wednesday night.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility to one half mile or less for extended periods of time.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM NOON TUESDAY TO MIDNIGHT AKST TUESDAY NIGHT FOR THOMPSON PASS

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 2:30PM AKST until December 4 at 3:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Freezing rain expected. Total ice accumulations of a light glaze.
* WHERE...Anchorage.
* WHEN...6 AM Tuesday to 3 AM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Difficult travel conditions are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Pockets of light freezing rain/drizzle are expected to develop Tuesday morning and continue throughout the day Tuesday. The best chance for ice accumulations will be in south and west Anchorage. Temperatures will rise above freezing Tuesday night, but rain can still freeze when hitting cold road and sidewalk surfaces.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM TUESDAY TO 3 AM AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 2:30PM AKST until December 4 at 6:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Freezing rain expected. Total ice accumulations of a light glaze.
* WHERE...Western Kenai Peninsula.
* WHEN...6 AM Tuesday to 6 AM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Difficult travel conditions are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Pockets of light freezing rain/drizzle are expected to develop Tuesday morning and continue throughout the day Tuesday into Tuesday night. Temperatures will rise above freezing by Wednesday morning, but rain can still freeze when hitting cold road and sidewalk surfaces.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM TUESDAY TO 6 AM AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 2:30PM AKST until December 5 at 3:00AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Freezing rain expected. Total ice accumulations of up to a few hundredths of an inch.
* WHERE...Susitna Valley.
* WHEN...From 3 PM Tuesday to 3 AM AKST Thursday
* IMPACTS...Difficult travel conditions are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Pockets of light freezing rain/drizzle are then expected to develop Tuesday afternoon and continue through Tuesday night into the day Wednesday. The best chance for ice accumulations will be west of the Parks Highway, but a glaze of ice is still possible in Talkeetna and and Willow. Precipitation may start as snow along the Alaska Range, particularly in Skwentna, with little to no snow accumulation expected.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 3 PM TUESDAY TO 3 AM AKST THURSDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 6:28PM EST by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
Light snow will diminish from northwest to southeast this evening.
With temperatures below freezing, roads will have slick areas on them, especially on bridges, overpasses, and untreated areas. Use caution if traveling and allow extra time to reach your destination.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Warren; Tippecanoe; Clinton; Fountain; Montgomery; Boone; Hamilton; Vermillion; Parke; Putnam; Hendricks; Marion; Hancock; Vigo; Clay; Owen; Morgan; Johnson; Shelby; Rush; Sullivan; Greene; Monroe; Brown; Bartholomew; Decatur; Knox; Daviess; Martin; Lawrence; Jackson; Jennings

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 5:27PM CST by NWS Paducah KY
entry.summary:
Light snow lingering this evening should exit all of the forecast area by 8 PM. While most of the accumulation has been confined to grassy and elevated surfaces, there have been numerous reports of slick roads causing accidents across the region. With air temperatures below freezing now, the potential for black ice will continue into the evening hours. Even once the snow ends, some scattered slick spots may remain.
Please use caution if travelling this evening, slow down, and leave extra time to reach your destination.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jefferson; Wayne; Edwards; Wabash; Perry; Franklin; Hamilton; White; Jackson; Williamson; Saline; Gallatin; Union; Johnson; Pope; Hardin; Alexander; Pulaski; Massac; Gibson; Pike; Posey; Vanderburgh; Warrick; Spencer; Fulton; Hickman; Carlisle; Ballard; McCracken; Graves; Livingston; Marshall; Calloway; Crittenden; Lyon; Trigg; Caldwell; Union; Webster; Hopkins; Christian; Henderson; Daviess; McLean; Muhlenberg; Todd; Perry; Bollinger; Cape Girardeau; Stoddard; Scott; Mississippi; New Madrid

entry.title: Freezing Fog Advisory issued December 2 at 2:58PM PST until December 3 at 11:00AM PST by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Visibilities one-quarter mile or less in freezing fog.
* WHERE...Foothills of the Southern Blue Mountains of Oregon and North Central Oregon.
* WHEN...Until 11 AM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Low visibility could make driving conditions hazardous.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Foothills of the Southern Blue Mountains of Oregon; North Central Oregon

cap:parameter.value: FREEZING FOG ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 AM PST TUESDAY

entry.title: Air Stagnation Advisory issued December 2 at 2:34PM PST until December 4 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A ridge of high pressure will lead to a strong inversion and stagnant air conditions near the surface that will continue to trap pollutants. This could worsen air quality over time.
* WHERE...Valley locations across southern Oregon. West of the Cascades, this includes the Umpqua, Illinois, Applegate, and Rogue valleys. East of the Cascades, this includes Klamath Falls, Sprague River, Chiloquin, Chemult, Silver Lake, Paisley, and surrounding areas.
* WHEN...For the Cold Weather Advisory, from 2 AM to 8 AM PST Monday.
For the Air Stagnation Advisory, until 4 PM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Low visibility could make driving conditions hazardous. Watch for icy spots on roads. Poor air quality may cause issues for people with respiratory problems.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Douglas County; Eastern Curry County and Josephine County; Jackson County; Klamath Basin; Northern and Eastern Klamath County and Western Lake County; Central and Eastern Lake County

cap:parameter.value: AIR STAGNATION ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 5:25PM EST by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
Snow will develop across eastern Kentucky this evening and fall for several hours before tapering to flurries towards midnight. Heavier bursts of snow will reduce visibility, potentially affecting traffic.
In addition, below freezing temperatures may result in slick spots on area bridges and overpasses. Travellers should use caution, slow down, and allow for extra braking distance.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Fleming; Montgomery; Bath; Rowan; Estill; Powell; Menifee; Rockcastle; Jackson; Pulaski; Laurel; Wayne; McCreary; Whitley; Knox; Elliott; Morgan; Johnson; Wolfe; Magoffin; Floyd; Lee; Breathitt; Knott; Owsley; Perry; Clay; Leslie; Martin; Pike

cap:parameter.value: Light Snowfall Expected Across Eastern Kentucky Tonight

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 5:12PM EST by NWS Northern Indiana
entry.summary: An band of moderate snow showers will continue to move southeast at around 15 mph. Rapidly changing visibility and snow covered roads can be expected with this band, causing a brief period of hazardous driving conditions. Major roads that will be impacted include the Indiana Toll Road between mile markers 95 and 135, Interstate 69 between mile markers 325 and 350 and portions of US 20 and 6. Slow down and give yourself extra stopping distance between vehicles when encountering this band.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lagrange; Steuben; Noble; De Kalb; St. Joseph; Branch

cap:parameter.value: Band of Moderate Snow to Impact portions of northeastern Indiana

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 3:48PM CST by NWS Paducah KY
entry.summary:
Light to moderate snow will continue to impact the region late this afternoon before exiting the region early this evening. Accumulations will range from a dusting to half an inch in many locations. However, localized amounts up to 1 inch are possible.
Most of the accumulations will be confined to grassy and elevated surfaces, but some slush may accumulate on a few untreated roads especially as we approach sunset and thereafter.
Allow a little extra time and drive carefully on your evening commute today.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jefferson; Wayne; Edwards; Wabash; Perry; Franklin; Hamilton; White; Jackson; Williamson; Saline; Gallatin; Union; Johnson; Pope; Hardin; Alexander; Pulaski; Massac; Gibson; Pike; Posey; Vanderburgh; Warrick; Spencer; Carlisle; Ballard; McCracken; Graves; Livingston; Marshall; Calloway; Crittenden; Lyon; Trigg; Caldwell; Union; Webster; Hopkins; Christian; Henderson; Daviess; McLean; Muhlenberg; Todd; Perry; Cape Girardeau

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 4:38PM EST by NWS Louisville KY
entry.summary:
Light snow will move through the area through this evening. Heavier showers will reduce visibility, potentially impacting rush hour traffic.
Below freezing temperatures may result in slick spots on bridges and overpasses. Drivers should use caution in these conditions, slow down and allow extra space between vehicles.

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued December 2 at 12:01PM AKST until December 4 at 6:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blizzard conditions possible. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Eastern Beaufort Sea Coast.
* WHEN...From Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Plan on difficult travel conditions. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 45 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 11:59AM AKST until December 3 at 12:00PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blowing snow expected. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph will reduce visibility to one half mile or less at times.
* WHERE...Dalton Highway Summits.
* WHEN...Until noon AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on hazardous travel conditions. Areas of blowing snow will significantly reduce visibility. Expect areas of significant drifting snow on the roadway. The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 40 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.

entry.title: Air Stagnation Advisory issued December 2 at 1:52PM MST until December 6 at 9:00PM MST by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
* WHAT...An extended period of stagnant air, with light winds and little vertical mixing. This is due to an inversion near the surface that will continue to trap pollutants in valleys.
Dense fog has decreased this afternoon, but will likely increase again this evening through Tuesday.
* WHERE...Lower Treasure Valley Zones.
* WHEN...Until 9 PM MST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Poor air quality may cause issues for people with respiratory problems.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Treasure Valley; Oregon Lower Treasure Valley

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 11:43AM AKST until December 3 at 6:00AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...HEAVY SNOW CONTINUES INTO MONDAY...
Heavy snow continues for the Haines area with warm temperatures aloft over Juneau and Gustavus transitioning precipitation type to a wintry mix, including freezing rain.
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches. Winds gusting as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...Municipality of Skagway.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL INFORMATION...Snow is now expected to continue through Monday night with temperatures rising much slower than initially expected. A period of freezing rain is likely before the snow fully transitions to rain.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM AKST TUESDAY

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued December 2 at 3:41PM EST until December 3 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Additional snow accumulations between 2 and 5 inches.
* WHERE...Ashtabula Inland, Ashtabula Lakeshore, and Lake Counties.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday evening and Tuesday morning commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A potent cold front will move through Wednesday night, ushering in strong, gusty winds and impactful lake effect snow Wednesday night into Thursday. Additional winter weather headlines may be needed for that period.

entry.summary:

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A potent cold front will move through Wednesday night, ushering in strong, gusty winds and impactful lake effect snow Wednesday night through Thursday night. The combination of snow and blowing snow may create significant travel impacts, and additional winter weather headlines will likely be needed for this period.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 3:38PM EST by NWS Wilmington OH
entry.summary:
Snow showers will begin to move across the area and continue into the early overnight hours, impacting the evening commute. While accumulations will be light, air temperatures will drop below freezing, resulting in the potential for some slick spots, especially on bridges and overpasses. Slippery roadways will linger overnight even after the snow ends given the cold pavement temperatures.
Motorists should exercise extra caution through the evening and overnight hours. What appears to be wet roads may actually be patches of ice, particularly if you drive over a bridge. Slow down and allow extra distance between you and other vehicles.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Franklin; Ripley; Dearborn; Ohio; Switzerland; Carroll; Gallatin; Boone; Kenton; Campbell; Owen; Grant; Pendleton; Bracken; Robertson; Mason; Lewis; Butler; Hamilton; Clermont; Brown; Adams

cap:parameter.value: SLICK ROADWAYS POSSIBLE THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued December 2 at 12:14PM PST until December 3 at 12:00PM PST by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor tidal overflow expected.
* WHERE...Beaches of San Diego County and Orange County.
* WHEN...Through Tuesday morning.
* IMPACTS...Minor tidal overflow during astronomical high tides around 6 feet Tuesday morning could inundate low lying locations, including parking lots. At highest risk are Imperial Beach, La Jolla Shores, Del Mar, Cardiff, Newport Beach, Sunset Beach and Seal Beach.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Time and height of highest tides each day:
Newport Beach - Tuesday: 6.01 feet at 916 AM.
La Jolla - Tuesday: 5.96 feet at 912 AM.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Diego County Coastal Areas; Orange County Coastal

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH TUESDAY MORNING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 3:12PM EST by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary: Snow will develop across southeast Kentucky this evening and fall for several hours before tapering to flurries during the early morning hours on Tuesday. Fluffy snow accumulations of a dusting to one half inch can be expected on the deep valley floors, increasing to between 1 and 2 inches above 2,500 feet. If traveling over the higher elevations this evening into Tuesday morning, slow down and use caution and be prepared for slippery spots. Impacted high-elevation highways include US-421, US-119 and US-23 on Pine Mountain, and KY-160 and KY-179 on Big Black Mountain and KY-74 over the Log Mountains.

cap:parameter.value: Light Snowfall Expected Across Mountains of Southeast Kentucky Tonight

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 2:50PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
Snow showers develop this evening in the North Carolina counties along the Tennessee border and continue overnight. Light accumulations of 1 to 3 inches, with locally higher amounts of 3-5 inches at elevations above 3500 feet are expected by daybreak Tuesday when snow showers taper off. Gusty northwest winds are also expected but should remain below 35 mph across most locations.
Slow down and use caution if traveling across the higher elevations tonight through Tuesday morning. Snow covered roadways across the higher terrain could impact travel conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Avery; Madison; Yancey; Mitchell; Swain; Haywood; Graham

cap:parameter.value: Snow Expected Across the Smoky Mountains and North Carolina- Tennessee Border Tonight

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 2:18PM EST by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
Snow will develop across southwest Virginia late this afternoon and tonight. Light snow accumulation of a dusting to one-half inch is possible across lower elevations. Locally higher amounts of 1 to 2 inches of snow accumulation will be possible across higher elevations above 2500 feet.
Cold temperatures will remain across the Tennessee Valley and Southern Appalachians early this week. Wind chills will drop into the single digits to near zero across the higher elevations.
Slow down and use caution if traveling across the higher elevations tonight through Tuesday morning. Be prepared for the possibilty of ice and snow covered roadways.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 2:18PM EST by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
Light snow will develop across the region this evening and tonight. Light snow accumulation of a dusting to one-half inch is possible. Localized higher amounts of 1 inch snow accumulation will be possible across the highest ridge and mountain peaks of the plateau, generally above 2500 feet.
Cold temperatures will remain across the Tennessee Valley and Southern Appalachians early this week. Wind chills will drop into the single digits to near zero across the higher elevations.
Slow down and use caution if traveling across the higher elevations tonight through Tuesday morning. Be prepared for the possibilty of ice and snow covered roadways across higher terrain.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued December 3 at 3:47AM ChST until December 4 at 5:00AM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents expected.
* WHERE...East facing reefs of the Marianas.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Elevated trade swell from a moderate trade-wind surge to the east has increased surf along east facing reefs, causing the risk of rip currents to become high. The trade- wind surge is expected to weaken around midweek, allowing the trade swell and surf to slowly diminish, and allowing the risk of rip currents to become moderate.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RISK OF RIP CURRENTS THROUGH LATE TONIGHT

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued December 2 at 8:23AM AKST until December 2 at 4:15PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Heavy rainfall across the southern panhandle has resulted in minor flooding near the Thorne River. Rainfall rates will diminish through the morning.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Thorne River near Areas Around The Thorne River Bridge.
* WHEN...Until 415 PM AKST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 820 AM AKST, river gauge reports indicate rises in water levels from heavy rain in areas around the Thorne River bridge. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly, especially near Thorne River. Between 3 and 6 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.25 to 1 inch are possible.
- For Thorne River near Thorne Bay: At 7:00am the stage was 12.9 feet. Flood Stage is 12.5 feet.
Impacts: At 12.5 feet: Water will begin to flow over the road upstream from the Thorne River bridge.

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 415 PM AKST THIS AFTERNOON

entry.summary:

* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Ward Lake near Areas Near The Ward Lake Recreational Area.
* WHEN...Until 745 AM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 740 AM AKST, the dam operator reported heavy rain in areas near the Ward Lake recreational area. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly, especially near Ward Lake.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 5:35AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Over the last 30 hours, portions of the southern panhandle have seen heavy rain with rainfall accumulations of over 1 inch, ranging to over 7 inches in parts of Ketchikan.
Heavy rain is expected to continue through Monday with another 1.5 to 3.5 inches, more at higher elevation, through 3 PM Monday.
Runoff will have a difficult time keeping up with this amount of rain, particularly in areas where the ground froze over the last week. Expect ponding of water on roadways and for flashy creeks to spike up. Boat owners should check on their vessels.
After a short-lived lull in the rain Monday night, another round of moderate to heavy rain is expected for Tuesday. 24 hour rainfall totals on Tuesday are expected to be 1 to 3 inches across the south.
Each round of heavy rain will have strong winds with gusts greater than 40 mph likely.
Please let the National Weather Service office know if you are seeing impacts from this rainfall.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: HEAVY RAIN AND STRONG WIND EXPECTED TO CONTINUE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 5:35AM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Snow is changing over to rain through the area today. A significant snow pack exists from the resent storm. Once the snow completely changes over to rain, an extended period of rain on snow is expected with rainfall continuing through Tuesday.
The rain will make snow removal difficult due to higher water content making the snow heavier. Areas of compact snow will become very slippery. There could also be areas of ponding of water due to blocked culverts or drains.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau

cap:parameter.value: RAIN ON SNOW WILL CREATE SLIPPERY CONDITIONS

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 2 at 4:39AM AKST until December 4 at 5:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Mixed precipitation expected. Total ice accumulations of a glaze up to one tenth of an inch and snow accumulations of up to two inches. North winds gusting as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...Bristol Bay.
* WHEN...From 3 PM this afternoon to 5 PM AKST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Multiple rounds of light precipitation will bring chances for freezing rain. The first round, beginning this afternoon, will bring chances for a trace to a few hundredths of an inch of ice mixed in with light snow. Another round of precipitation Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday brings higher chances and greater amounts of freezing rain. The best chances for freezing rain and greatest accumulation will occur along a line roughly from Dillingham north through Koliganek, in the area east of the Ahklun Mountains. However, at least a glaze of ice is possible across most of the area. Precipitation will switch to rain from east to west on Wednesday as winds shift out of the southeast.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 3 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 5 PM AKST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued December 2 at 4:02AM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary: Bands of snowfall across the Pribilof Islands could become heavier as the back side of a strong low pressure system moves across the Bering Sea through Tuesday afternoon. Due to the showery nature of these snow bands, the exact timing and intensity could vary. Additionally, visibility may be reduced to one quarter mile at times with gusty east winds up to 35 mph, becoming southeast this afternoon. Snowfall rates and winds may diminish as early as Monday night, however there is potential for hazardous conditions to last through Tuesday afternoon.

cap:parameter.value: PERIODS OF HEAVY SNOWFALL AND BLOWING SNOW POSSIBLE FOR THE PRIBILOF ISLANDS THROUGH TUESDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued December 2 at 3:11AM EST until December 3 at 4:00AM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A strong, southward-flowing longshore current is forecast to develop at all central Florida Atlantic beaches today, along with a moderate risk for dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...Coastal Volusia, Coastal Brevard, Coastal Indian River, Coastal Saint Lucie, and Coastal Martin counties.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...The southward-flowing current could pull swimmers into deeper water, making them more susceptible to dangerous rip currents. This will also generate strong rip currents near piers, jetties, and reefs.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Volusia; Coastal Indian River; Coastal St. Lucie; Coastal Martin; Mainland Northern Brevard; Northern Brevard Barrier Islands; Mainland Southern Brevard; Southern Brevard Barrier Islands

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE TONIGHT
